explanation:
Correct calculation: Given 3 squares correspond to 6cm, each square represents \(6 \div 3 = 2\ \text{cm}\). The star's 1-square length is \(1 \times 2 = 2\ \text{cm}\).

Student's error: They likely calculated \(1\ \text{square} \times 1\ \text{cm/square} = 1\ \text{cm}\), assuming each grid unit equals 1cm without verifying the scale.

Flaw: The student failed to derive the scale from the provided side length (3 squares = 6cm). This caused them to default to an implicit 1:1 grid-to-cm ratio instead of calculating \(6 \div 3 = 2\ \text{cm/square}\).

Distinction: Unlike estimation errors, this directly stems from not using the given labeled side to establish proportionality. It differs from grid-point counting, as squares (not points) were explicitly referenced in the problem. The error centers on scale derivation, not geometric properties of hexagons.
